a TM atom adsorbed on each of the high-symmetry sites of interest on the Ti2C MXene surface: hollow above a carbon atom (HC), hollow above a titanium atom (HTi), bridge (B), and top (T). The rhombus (green line) represents the shape and size of the computational supercell used in the calculations. The spheres represent atoms of titanium (in silver), carbon (in black), or a TM element (in yellow). Fig 1 Fig. 2 Top views (top images) and side views (bottom images) of N2 molecular adsorption (left figures), dissociation transition state (centre figures), and dissociated state (right figures) on the Ti2C MXene surface. The spheres represent atoms of titanium (in silver), carbon (in black), or nitrogen (in blue). Fig 2 Fig. 3 Top views of N2 adsorption configurations on some TM@Ti2C surfaces, in which the most stable adsorption site of the TM adatom is B (left image), HC (centre image), or HTi (right image). The images were drawn using the coordinates for TM = Hf, Ni and Zn, respectively, but the configurations shown are representative of all the TMs above each of the panels. The spheres represent atoms of titanium (in silver), carbon (in black), nitrogen (blue), or a TM element (in yellow). Fig 3 Fig. 4 Adsorption energy, of one N2 molecule on the TM@Ti2C systems studied in this work. The black box contains the cases in which the molecule is unable to adsorb while forming bonds with the TM atom. The dashed line is set at the adsorption energy of N2 on the Ti2C MXene surface (without the TM atom). Fig 4 Fig. 5 Projected density of states (DOS, left) and Crystal Orbital Hamilton Population (COHP, right) of N2 on Sc@Ti2C (top rows), Co@Ti2C (middle) and Cd@Ti2C (bottom). Fig 5 Fig. 6 Top views of transition state configurations of N2 dissociation on some TM@Ti2C surfaces, in which the most stable adsorption site of the TM atom is B (left image), HC (centre image), or HTi (right image). Industrial ammonia production follows the Haber-Bosch process, whose rate-limiting step is the dissociation of the nitrogen molecule (N2), hence requiring suitable catalysts to break its triple bond. MXenes, a class of two-dimensional transition metal carbides and nitrides, have been proposed as very efficient catalysts for N2 dissociation. Here, by employing density functional theory-based calculations, we assess whether the deposition of one atom of a transition metal element (TM) on the Ti2C MXene surface further improves the catalytic potential of the MXene, serving as a single-atom catalyst. The results show that, for 21 of the 30 TMs considered, N2 can exothermically bind to the TM adatom, this bonding being favourable with respect to adsorption on the pristine Ti2C MXene surface for TMs of groups 3 to 6 of the Periodic Table. All the 21 TMs that successfully bind to N2 effectively reduce the N2 dissociation energy barrier when compared to the bulk Ti2C MXene by 18 to 84 %. Our results strongly indicate that doping the Ti2C MXene with atoms of transition metal elements significantly reduces the energy required to break the triple bond in N2, which may impact the nitrogen-to-ammonia process. Introduction The Haber-Bosch (HB) process is the dominating means of industrial production of ammonia (NH3) today [1]. This compound is the precursor of many others containing nitrogen, which have application, for example, in areas such as the pharmaceutical industry, as fertilizers, or as cleaning products [2]. Ammonia has also been proposed as an energy carrier due to its high hydrogen capacity and energy density [3,4]. The HB process converts atmospheric nitrogen (N2) and hydrogen (H2) into ammonia. The most challenging step of this conversion is the dissociation of N2 molecules, since their triple covalent bond is extremely strong, with a dissociation energy close to 10 eV. This obstacle has driven much of the research in this area to focus on finding catalysts that can reduce the N2 dissociation activation energy. Well established catalysts include Fe(111) surfaces, displaying an experimentally measured barrier for N2 dissociation around 0.8 eV [5], or Ru nanoparticles, on which the same energy barrier is in the 0.4–1.9 eV range, depending on the surface site considered [6]. Other materials, such as V(110) surfaces, provide energy barriers of the same order [7]. Despite greatly facilitating N2 dissociation, the usage of these materials in the HB process still requires temperatures around 450 °C and pressures of several hundred bar [1]. One way to allow HB synthesis to be operated at milder conditions is to find catalysts that can further reduce the energy barrier for N2 dissociation. MXenes are two-dimensional materials discovered just over 10 years ago [8]. They are made up of very few close-packed layers of early transition metal elements intercalated with layers of carbon or nitrogen. Depending on the synthesis procedure, MXenes may include different surface terminations bound to the outer metallic atomic layers, but post-synthesis heating treatments have been used successfully to obtain MXenes devoid of surface termination [9,10]. These bare MXenes are stable[11] and their potential in catalysis is well known [12]. In particular, MXenes have been shown to be suitable catalysts for hydrogen production via the water-gas shift reaction [10,13,14], for CO2 reduction to CO[15–17] and, most importantly here, for N2 dissociation [18–20]. In fact, some MXenes have been predicted to be able to reduce the energy barrier for N2 dissociation by over 95 %, e.g. up to 0.18 eV on Mo2N. The Ti2C MXene is expected to exothermically adsorb and dissociate N2, with an energy barrier of 0.98 eV. Unfortunately, some of the MXenes predicted to be the best for dissociating N2, such as W2N, have not been synthesised to date [21]. Since the titanium carbide MXene was the first to be manufactured, it is naturally the most studied and well-known member of the MXene family, but regrettably is not amongst the most promising MXenes for serving as a catalyst in the HB process in its pristine form. However, because it has been synthesised so many times, its production method is already very optimized and, for this reason, it is scientifically desirable to improve on its properties by tweaking its composition or structure. One such tweak could be the doping of the Ti2C MXene surface with atoms of other transition metal (TM) elements, which has been considered by numerous studies, and found to often improve the catalytic activity of the MXene. For example, a Zn@Ti2CN2 single-atom catalyst (SAC) was very recently predicted to reduce the CO oxidation energy barrier to a mere 0.06 eV [22], and a Pt@Ti3C2 SAC was experimentally shown to very efficiently fixate CO2 [23]. This led us and other researchers to conduct systematic analyses of the interaction of MXenes with atoms of transition metal elements [24,25], by which we found that very stable TM@MXene complexes are formed. This again hints at their potential for applications such as catalysis, and that is the subject of the present work. In this work, we examine the interaction between single transition metal atoms of 30 different chemical elements, deposited on the Ti2C MXene surface, and a nitrogen molecule. To this end, we calculate N2 adsorption configurations and energies in the vicinity of each TM atom, the N2 dissociation activation energy starting from its adsorbed configuration, and the dissociation energy. Lastly, we compare the results found for each TM element with the ones on the bulk Ti2C MXene surface. In the sections that follow, we first describe the computational methods and models used, then present and discuss the results found, and finally summarize the main conclusions. Computational methods and models The Ti2C MXene surface was modelled as a supercell containing 4 × 4 unit cells (48 atoms) of the material, with periodic boundary conditions in all cartesian directions. A width of circa 18 Å of vacuum was inserted in the direction perpendicular to the slab to avoid interaction between periodic copies of the system. Fig. 1 shows the MXene model considered in this work, with a TM atom adsorbed in four different high-symmetry sites of the surface: hollow carbon (HC), hollow titanium (HTi), bridge (B), and top (T). Table 1 shows the most stable adsorption site of an atom of each of the TM elements studied here on the Ti2C MXene, taken from Ref. [24], where the adsorption energies of TM adatoms on Ti2C can also be found. Notice that Fig. 1 includes a model of the Ti2C MXene with a TM atom adsorbed on a T site despite none of the TM preferring this site. This is for the sake of completeness since some TM atoms may move to a T site upon nearby N2 adsorption and/or dissociation. The TM elements chosen were those of the fourth, fifth and sixth periods of the Periodic Table, with Lu representing the lanthanoids, since its electronic configuration and adsorption behaviour on Ti2C are the most similar to those of the remaining elements of this period, due to the filled 4f subshell [24]. The density functional theory (DFT) calculations were carried out using the VASP package [26]. The exchange correlation functional of choice was PBE [27], including dispersion interactions via the D3 method by Grimme [28]. This selection is known to accurately describe adsorption phenomena on MXenes[29,30] and has been used in previous works, allowing method consistency and comparison of results [20,31]. Previous theoretical studies on the application of SACs in electrochemical processes have shown that the use of hybrid functionals may yield significantly different results [32,33]. In the case of MXenes without SACs, the PBE and HSE functionals have been reported to give similar results, with the exception of band gap values [34–36]. Valence electron wave functions were expanded in a plane wave basis set with an energy cut-off of 415 eV, while core electrons were treated using the projector augmented wave (PAW) method [37]. The valence configurations of individual atoms are the same as in [Ref. 24]. Our preliminary tests showed that, to obtain relative energies converged within 1 meV/atom, a gamma-centred Monkhorst-Pack grid of 3 × 3 × 1 k-points[38] adequately samples the Brillouin zone. From the results of these tests, we additionally settled for atomic nuclei relaxations to be considered converged once no atoms felt net forces over 0.001 eV/Å, while the total energy calculations stopped when the difference between consecutive steps was lower than 10−6 eV. Spin polarization was considered in all calculations. For each TM@Ti2C, we searched for the most stable adsorption configuration of N2, by initially placing the molecule vertically or horizontally over each relevant site of the surface in the vicinity of the TM atom, optimizing the positions of the atoms, and comparing the final total energies. We then took each ground state N2 adsorption configuration and calculated the adsorption energy of N2 on each TM@Ti2C as E ads = E TM @ T i 2 C + N 2 − ( E TM @ T i 2 C + E N 2 ) . Here, the E TM @ T i 2 C + N 2 , E TM @ T i 2 C and E N 2 are the total energies of supercells containing the Ti2C MXene surface with a TM atom and a nitrogen molecule adsorbed, the Ti2C MXene surface with a TM atom, and a nitrogen molecule, respectively. In this work, all the calculated adsorption energies are negative, indicating exothermic adsorption, meaning that values farther from zero imply stronger adsorption. The N2 dissociation activation energies, E barr, were calculated as the difference between the total energy of TM@Ti2C+N2 in its transition ( E TM @ T i 2 C + N 2 , TS ) and molecular ( E TM @ T i 2 C + N 2 ) states, E barr = E TM @ T i 2 C + N 2 − E TM @ T i 2 C + N 2 , TS . The transition states were obtained using the dimer method [39]. This method allows one to find first-order saddle points of the potential energy hypersurface of the system, which was verified by calculating the normal vibrational modes of the adsorbed N2 in the state found by the dimer approach and checking that a single imaginary frequency was present. The vibration of the molecule in the mode with the imaginary frequency corresponds to oscillation between the adsorbed molecular and dissociated states, thus providing us with information on the configuration of the system after N2 dissociates. The N2 dissociation reaction energy was obtained as the difference between the total energies of the supercells containing N2 adsorbed in its dissociated ( E TM @ T i 2 C + 2 N ) and molecular ( E TM @ T i 2 C + N 2 ) states, E reac = E TM @ T i 2 C + 2 N − E TM @ T i 2 C + N 2 . All total energies of systems involving N2 include the zero-point energy corrections, calculated using the harmonic approximation and considering the vibrational degrees of freedom of the molecule. Results and discussion The mechanism of N2 dissociation on the pristine Ti2C MXene surface was studied in a previous work, employing a supercell size of 3 × 3 MXene unit cells [19]. The calculated N2 adsorption energy, N2 activation energy, and N2 dissociation reaction energy were −3.26 eV, 0.98 eV, and −1.55 eV, respectively. Here, for the sake of consistency with the calculations involving the TM atoms, we briefly revisited this problem using the same parameters that we use in the rest of the calculations, including a wider 4 × 4 supercell. Structurally, we found the same adsorption, activated and dissociated state configurations, as can be seen in Fig. 2 . The molecule adsorbs with one N atom on each of two neighbouring hollow sites (HC and HTi), and its dissociation involves a jump of the N atom adsorbed on HC to HTi, so that ultimately, each N atom sits on its most stable adsorption site, HTi. The interatomic distances surrounding the N2 molecule obtained here differ by less than 1 % from the ones found in the previous work. For example, the newly obtained N-N distance is 1.35 Å, similar to the 1.36 Å found in [Ref. 19]. Energetically, some differences were found. The adsorption energy calculated on the 4 × 4 supercell is lower than on the 3 × 3 one by 0.28 eV, standing for an adsorption that is 9 % stronger. This was expected since, on a smaller supercell, there is stronger repulsion between the periodic replicas of the molecule, and its adsorption involves a more pronounced lattice distortion, leading to lower stability. In turn, the N2 dissociation energy barrier calculated on the 4 × 4 supercell is higher by 0.09 eV, and the dissociation was predicted to be less exothermic by 0.12 eV. To verify that the results are converged with respect to supercell size, we also compared the mechanism of N2 adsorption and dissociation on a 5 × 5 Ti2C supercell vs. a 4 × 4 one and found energetic differences of less than 0.03 eV. In the following subsections, we analyse the N2 adsorption and dissociation mechanism on the Ti2C MXene surface in the vicinity of a TM adatom, and compare it with the one predicted for the clean MXene. N2 adsorption Regardless of the TM atom added to the Ti2C MXene surface, the N2 molecule always adsorbs preferably on the same lattice sites as the ones found for the pristine Ti2C, i.e., with one of its atoms on an HC site and the other on an adjacent HTi site. The TM elements considered in this work can be divided into two sets depending on their behaviour towards N2 adsorption on TM@Ti2C: metals from the first set form no chemical bonds with N2, and metals from the second set form a bond with at least one of the N atoms. For the metals of the first set (Ru, Rh, Pd, Ag, Cd, Ir, Pt, Au and Hg), no N2 adsorption configurations on TM@Ti2C with TM-N2 bonds are stable, and the molecule can only adsorb far from the TM adatom, at least 4 Å away. In this set, all the calculated adsorption energies are higher than on the clean Ti2C MXene, indicating weaker adsorption. This suggests that, in these situations, the molecule attempts to adsorb as far from the TM adatom as possible, on the bulk Ti2C MXene, but due to the finite size of the model, it still interacts weakly with TM adatom and is affected by the electronic and structural changes on the Ti2C surface that this adatom induces. Fig. 3 shows the N2 adsorption configurations on the TM@Ti2C, for the TM elements of the second set. Three images are shown, each one representative of all TMs that adsorb on a different lattice site, and the average N-N distance is 1.38 Å, which is a little higher than the one calculated for the Ti2C Mxene by 0.03 Å, and 23 % higher than the 1.12 Å calculated for gaseous N2, indicating molecule activation. As can be seen, each TM adatom remains adsorbed in its original lattice site, only slightly dislocated because of the presence of the adsorbed N2 species nearby. The N2 adsorption configurations depicted in Fig. 3 are not the only stable ones. The molecule can also adsorb by bonding only to the TM adatom, either by sitting parallel (η2-bonding) or perpendicularly (η1-bonding) to the plane of the surface, in a manner similar to the one observed for H2 or O2 adsorptions on SACs deposited on nitrogen-doped graphene in Refs. [40,41], respectively. These configurations are almost equally stable, with a slight tendency for the perpendicular one, but both are less stable than the ground state by at least 2.5 eV. As one would expect, parallel adsorption on top of the TM adatom stretches the N-N bond and can facilitate dissociation. This stretching is much less noticeable than in the ground state configuration, with an average N-N distance of 1.17 Å, hinting that N2 dissociation is much cheaper energetically when starting from the ground state adsorption configuration. The N2 adsorption energies on all TM@Ti2C systems are shown in Fig. 4 and Table S1. Concerning metals of the second set, even though N2 adsorption close to the TM adatom is stable in all cases, it is only energetically advantageous with respect to adsorption on the pristine Ti2C MXene surface for metals of groups 3 to 6 of the Periodic Table. Nitrogen can adsorb bonded to the remaining metals of this set, but this is a metastable adsorption configuration. Although the TM@Ti2C surfaces with TM adsorbed on a B site display the highest affinity towards N2, there are no clear changes of behaviour in terms of N2 adsorption for TM adatoms that prefer different lattice sites. On all the TM@Ti2C systems with TM in the fourth period of the Periodic Table, the TM adatom is able to form a chemical bond with N2, with the TM-N2 interaction being strongest for Sc@Ti2C, with E ads = −4.00 eV, becoming weaker as we move along this period, achieving its weakest intensity for Co@Ti2C, with E ads = −2.81 eV, and then becoming stronger again. The lines corresponding to the TM elements of the fifth and sixth periods of the Periodic Table in Fig. 4 appear to attempt to follow the same behaviour as that of the fourth period – adsorption is strongest for metals from the leftmost groups and becomes weaker as one moves along the period. However, instead of peaking on group 9, they peak earlier, on the last TM element of each period that can bond with N2 on the TM@Ti2C surface. This is most likely due to the inability of TM@Ti2C with one of the last TM elements of periods 5 and 6 to bind N2, which necessarily causes the N2 adsorption energy on these surfaces to approach the one of the clean Ti2C MXene. To analyse the TM-N2 bonds in terms of electronic structure, we calculated the density of states (DOS), projected onto the TM adatom and the two N atoms of N2 adsorbed in every TM@Ti2C surface studied here. Fig. 5 shows the resulting plots for Sc@Ti2C, Co@Ti2C and Cd@Ti2C as examples and the plots for the remaining elements are shown in Figures S2, S3 and S4. The highest DOS of N2 is found on three peaks around 6 eV and around 2 eV below the Fermi energy, and most TMs also display DOS peaks at the same locations, as in the examples of Sc@Ti2C and Co@Ti2C (Fig. 5). The ones that do not present the same DOS features (e.g. Cd@Ti2C in Fig. 5) are the TMs that do not allow N2 to adsorb within bonding distance on TM@Ti2C, suggesting that the formation of a chemical bond with N2 is related to hybridization of electronic states near this energy range. To confirm this, we performed a crystal orbital Hamilton population (COHP) analysis[42,43] which provides information about the bonding or antibonding character to the band-structure energy, with results for the projected COHP (-pCOHP) N-N and N-TM bonding displayed in Fig. 5. In this context, a more positive -pCOHP value is associated with stronger bonding. As can be seen, the regions of interest are the same as those referred to in the analyses of the DOS, with significant N-TM bonding regions in the Sc@Ti2C and Co@Ti2C systems and negligible interactions for Cd@Ti2C. The integrated COHP (-IpCOHP) up to the Fermi level for the N-N interactions are 1.54, 2.07 and 2.12, for Sc@Ti2C, Co@Ti2C and Cd@Ti2C, respectively, showing that the N-N bond is more activated in the former, which is a consequence of the N-TM bonding that is greater in the case of Sc@Ti2C (average value for TM-Nnear and TM-Nfar bonding of 2.46) than on Co@Ti2C (average value of 1.58) and Cd@Ti2C (average value of 0.07). N2 dissociation Like N2 adsorption, N2 dissociation on the TM@Ti2C SACs also occurs in a manner similar to the mechanism on the Ti2C MXene surface. Namely, the N adatom that lies on HTi remains on this site, while the other N adatom moves from HC to a neighbouring HTi site, leading both N adatoms to finally sit on their most stable surface site. For TM@Ti2C systems in which the TM does not form a bond with N2, the N2 dissociation transition state is structurally nearly identical to the one on the Ti2C MXene. For the remaining TM elements, Fig. 6 shows the N2 dissociation transition state configurations for metals that adsorb on each surface site. Tables S2, S3 and S4 contain the N-N distance on each TM@Ti2C surface, for the adsorbed, transition and dissociated state of N2, respectively. Considering only the TM elements that bind N2 on TM@Ti2C, the average N-N distance in the transition state configuration is 1.77 Å, representing an increase of 27 % with respect to the molecular adsorption state. Whereas the average N-N bond length in the N2 adsorbed state is higher on TM@Ti2C than on Ti2C by 0.03 Å, the same bond length in the transition state is considerably shorter on TM@Ti2C than on Ti2C, by 0.14 Å. This means that, while on the Ti2C MXene the N-N bond length needs to increase by 0.56 Å for the dissociation transition state to be reached, on TM@Ti2C a stretching of 0.39 Å is enough on average. The fact that the bond length does not need to change as much for the reaction transition state to be achieved reveals an early transition state and is typical of a lower activation energy. The calculated N2 dissociation energy barriers on TM@Ti2C are shown in Fig. 7 and Table S5. The different behaviour of TM adatoms that can or cannot bind N2 on TM@Ti2C is well reflected in the corresponding N2 dissociation energy barriers. As expected, the latter exhibit energy barriers remarkably close to the one on the pristine Ti2C MXene, with a maximum deviation of 4 % (Ru@Ti2C), while the former differ by at least 18 % (Cu@Ti2C) and at most 84 % (Hf@Ti2C and W@Ti2C). Thus, the presence of TM adatoms that do not bind to N2 on the Ti2C MXene surface does not affect the N2 dissociation energy barrier. On the other hand, all the other TM adatoms effectively reduce this energy barrier by at least 18 % with respect to the bulk Ti2C MXene. The W@Ti2C SAC provides one of the lowest calculated energy barriers, 0.17 eV, which is noteworthy since W2N, a W-based MXene, has been predicted to be the pristine MXene that most easily dissociates N2, with an activation energy of 0.18 eV [20]. Many of the energy barriers calculated here are lower than the ones found for transition metal-based industrial catalysts, such as Fe or Ru, which display values above 0.4 eV, representing an advantage of the TM@Ti2C MXene surfaces. The configurations of adsorbed N2 in its dissociate state, with dissociation catalysed by TM@Ti2C surfaces in which the TM adatom binds to N2, are shown in Fig. 8 . If the TM element adsorbs on a HC (Fig. 8c) or HTi (Fig. 8d) surface site, it remains on this site upon N2 adsorption and dissociation, during which one of the N adatoms moves farther from both the other N and the TM adatoms. However, TM adatoms that adsorb preferably on a B site do not remain on this site after N2 dissociates. Instead, depending on the TM element, they move to either a nearby HC (Sc, Ti, or V, see Fig. 8a) or T (Y, Zr, Lu, Hf, or Ta, see Fig. 8b) site. Furthermore, these TM adatoms remain bonded to both N atoms after N2 dissociation, and have much smaller N-N distances after N2 dissociation (2.92 Å on average, see Table S4) than the other TM@Ti2C cases (3.19 Å on average). Figure S6 illustrates the two possible mechanisms for N2 dissociation near TM@Ti2C where TM adsorbs on a B site. This Figure shows that, as one N adatom moves from an HC site in the molecular state to an HTi site in the dissociated state, the TM adatom moves from a B site in the molecular state to an adjacent T site in the transition state. Finally, depending on the TM element, it can stay on the T site in the dissociated state, or further move to an HC site. For the latter to occur, the TM adatom must go through the line connecting the two N adatoms, or over it. Notice that the TMs that move to a HC site belong to the 4th period of the Periodic Table, while the ones that remain on the T site belong to the 5th and 6th periods. This suggests that the latter may be kinetically inhibited from moving to the HC site. To verify this, we took the dissociated configurations for TM = Y, Zr, Lu, Hf, and Ta, moved the TM adatom to the HC site, and reoptimized the atomic positions. The conclusion was that this new position is indeed more stable than the T site, by 0.4 to 0.7 eV, depending on the TM. Consequently, all the TM adatoms that adsorb preferably on a B site on Ti2C tend to thermodynamically move to an HC site after catalysing N2 dissociation, but the heavier ones, those of the 5th and 6th periods, are kinetically inhibited to do so and instead stay on the intermediate T site. The calculated N2 dissociation reaction energies on TM@Ti2C are displayed in Fig. 9 and Table S7. The reaction is clearly exothermic regardless of the TM element, especially in the cases in which the TM adatom adsorbs N2. For some TM elements, N2 dissociation on TM@Ti2C is more exothermic than on the Ti2C MXene by several eV. This indicates that N2 dissociation is thermodynamically very favourable, but may be undesired for catalytic applications, as the products of reactions that are too exothermic tend to be adsorbed too strongly on the surface, hindering its regeneration. In addition, as can be seen by comparing Fig. 7 and Fig. 9, the TM@Ti2C SACs that allow the lowest N2 dissociation energy barriers tend to be the ones that dissociate N2 more exothermically. Consequently, a balance must be found between a very easy N2 dissociation while risking having a hard time regenerating the catalyst, and a slightly higher energy barrier that leads to a less exothermic reaction and facilitates the restoration of the catalyst. As an attempt to find such a balance, and since we seek the lowest possible energy barrier accompanied by the least exothermic N2 dissociation, one can define the quantity α = E barr + | E reac | , which yields a lower number for lower energy barriers and a less exothermic reaction. The TM element for which α is lowest is Co, with the corresponding TM@Ti2C surface allowing N2 to dissociate with an energy barrier of 0.54 eV, which is half the one on the pristine Ti2C MXene, and a dissociation energy of −1.71 eV, that is, more exothermic than on the Ti2C MXene by only 0.28 eV. On the Ti2C and Co@Ti2C MXene surfaces, we recalculated the N2 dissociation reaction and activation energies, by doing single point energy calculations using the HSE06 hybrid functional [44]. On both materials, this functional predicted the energy barrier to be higher by 0.19 eV and the reaction to be more exothermic by 0.22 eV, so it is possible that HSE06 systematically yields such differences for other MXenes or SACs. Note that the HSE06 energies were obtained by single-point calculations on the PBE-relaxed structures, which is the usual method due to the extremely high computational demand of HSE06 calculations, especially when using the plane-wave formalism [45]. It is common for reactions of the same family to follow a linear relationship between activation and reaction energy, known as a Brønsted-Evans-Polanyi relationship [46,47]. Here, this appears to not be the case. Figure S5 shows a plot of E barr vs E reac for the 18 TM@Ti2C MXene surfaces studied in this work. By observation, the relationship between these two quantities is clearly not linear; the corresponding correlation coefficient is 0.75. Instead, as we move from right to left on the plot of Figure S5, the reaction energies decrease, while the energy barriers appear to decrease more slowly, while the straight line predicts negative N2 dissociation energy barriers for the TM@Ti2C surfaces on which the N2 adsorption energy is below −3 eV, which does not make sense. We attempted an exponential fit to the data points, and found a much more appropriate fit, with a correlation coefficient of 0.96. For ammonia synthesis to be completed, not only does nitrogen need to dissociate, but hydrogen also needs to adsorb and dissociate, and each resulting N adatom should be hydrogenated three times. On the pristine Ti2C MXene surface, H2 dissociates spontaneously [48]. On the other hand, the hydrogenation steps are expected to not occur as easily [19,20]. Table 2 shows the energy barriers and reaction energies for the successive N hydrogenations that lead to the formation of NH3, as calculated for W2N, Ti2C and Co@Ti2C. Data from W2N were obtained in Ref. [19], where microkinetic calculations showed that ammonia synthesis via the Haber-Bosch formula is not possible, since the hydrogenation does not get past the NH2 species. Generally speaking, the W2N MXene displays the lowest N hydrogenation energy barriers amongst the three materials in Table 2, and Co@Ti2C the highest. While the first hydrogenation is exothermic on the clean Ti2C MXene, it is endothermic, by 0.91 eV, on Co@Ti2C. Therefore, on Ti2C, the reaction is more likely to proceed in the forward direction than in reverse, effectively producing NH, but on Co@Ti2C the opposite is expected, since the forward activation energy is 1.65 eV and the backward one only 0.74 eV. On Co@Ti2C, the subsequent hydrogenations are even more energetically demanding, with energy barriers above 2 eV, and more endothermic, with reaction energies of 0.99 and 1.95 eV, respectively. Overall, these values are much higher than on either W2N or Ti2C. This suggests that hydrogenation towards NH3 is most likely kinetically inhibited on a TM@Ti2C MXene surface, more so than on clean Ti2C. In a sense, the doping of the MXene surface with atoms of transition metal elements enhances the usual behaviour of the original material, by further facilitating N2 dissociation, and further hindering the hydrogenation of the resulting N adatoms. These findings lead to the recommendation of combining TM@Ti2C MXenes with, for example, Ru nanoparticles to effectively realize ammonia synthesis via the Haber-Bosch route. So far, we have assumed that ammonia synthesis on these surfaces should follow a dissociative mechanism. This is because, firstly, from previous experience, we know that MXenes devoid of a surface termination excel at breaking adsorbed species into smaller ones and, therefore, it is difficult to form larger species on their surfaces [13,29]. Secondly, because the calculated N2 dissociation activation energies are so small that it becomes very unlikely that any other ammonia synthesis mechanism would be kinetically easier. Nevertheless, for the sake of completeness, we explored the possibility of an associative pathway on four systems: Ti2C, Co@Ti2C, Cu@Ti2C and Ti@Ti2C, i.e., the bare MXene and one TM@Ti2C MXene for each N2 adsorption configuration seen in Fig. 3. For that, we studied the N2* + H* → NNH* reaction by hydrogenating either one of the N adatoms, for a total of 8 calculated activation energies and reaction energies. We found that the hydrogenation occurs preferably on the N adatom that is sitting on a HC surface site. However, the reaction is endothermic in all cases, by 0.27 to 1.4 eV, and involves an energy barrier between 1.15 and 2.02 eV. Given the much lower activation and reaction energies calculated for N2 dissociation on the TM@Ti2C MXene surfaces, these results indicate that the dissociative pathway is favoured. Conclusions In summary, we have employed density functional theory-based calculations to assess the potential of single-atom catalysts, consisting of an atom of a transition metal element deposited on the Ti2C MXene surface, to dissociate N2, the rate-limiting step of the Haber-Bosch process for ammonia synthesis. To achieve this goal, we built 30 surface models of the Ti2C MXene, each with an atom of a different transition metal adsorbed on its most stable surface site. Then, on each of these models, we calculated the N2 adsorption energy, dissociation energy barrier, and dissociation energy. For 9 out of the 30 cases, viz. Ru, Rh, Pd, Ag, Cd, Ir, Pt, Au and Hg, the nitrogen molecule adsorbs far from the transition metal adatom, and its adsorption and dissociation mechanisms are nearly identical to those on the clean Ti2C MXene, indicating that atoms of these elements supported on this MXene do not significantly change its catalytic activity towards N2 dissociation. For the remaining 21 transition metals, N2 adsorption is exothermic, but it is only more advantageous when compared to adsorption on the bulk Ti2C MXene for metals of groups 3 to 6 of the Periodic Table. Nevertheless, according to our calculations, a single adatom of any of these 21 elements effectively reduces the N2 dissociation activation energy with respect to the clean Ti2C MXene, by 18 to 84 %. The reaction was found to be more exothermic than on the Ti2C MXene in all cases. In conclusion, we found that single-atom catalysts, based on the majority of the transition metal elements considered here, represent a significant improvement of the catalytic activity of the Ti2C MXene surface for dissociating N2. One shortcoming of the models used in this work is the lack of MXene surface termination, known to be present upon MXene synthesis. This may be the subject of future work. Further analysis may also include the investigation of the effect of single transition metal adatoms in the catalytic activity towards N2 dissociation of other MXenes that have been synthesised, such as V2C, Nb2C or Mo2C, and whether MXene thickness affects the catalytic behaviour. coredata.dc:description: Industrial ammonia production follows the Haber-Bosch process, whose rate-limiting step is the dissociation of the nitrogen molecule (N2), hence requiring suitable catalysts to break its triple bond. MXenes, a class of two-dimensional transition metal carbides and nitrides, have been proposed as very efficient catalysts for N2 dissociation. Here, by employing density functional theory-based calculations, we assess whether the deposition of one atom of a transition metal element (TM) on the Ti2C MXene surface further improves the catalytic potential of the MXene, serving as a single-atom catalyst. The results show that, for 21 of the 30 TMs considered, N2 can exothermically bind to the TM adatom, this bonding being favourable with respect to adsorption on the pristine Ti2C MXene surface for TMs of groups 3 to 6 of the Periodic Table. All the 21 TMs that successfully bind to N2 effectively reduce the N2 dissociation energy barrier when compared to the bulk Ti2C MXene by 18 to 84 %. Our results strongly indicate that doping the Ti2C MXene with atoms of transition metal elements significantly reduces the energy required to break the triple bond in N2, which may impact the nitrogen-to-ammonia process.
